author: Ryan McDonald
title: Utes take to Twitter over LDS institute issue
text:
Current and former University of Utah players express opinions on social media about a letter sent to the university urging it to stop coaches from teaching an LDS Church institute class.
More Coverage Utah football: Chase Hansen just wants to play Not long after a letter was sent to the University of Utah on Tuesday asking it to stop Ute football coaches from teaching classes similar to those taught through The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints' Institute of Religion near campus, a bevy of current and former players let their opinions on the issue be known via Twitter.
The consensus: They weren't fans of the request, which was made by Americans United for the Separation of Church and State, an organization based in Washington, D.C.
A roundup of some of the tweets sent by the current and former players, most of them linked to a story written Tuesday by KSL's Josh Furlong:
What a joke!! Football provides countless opportunities of all kinds. Life must be extremely boring for this org.... https://t.co/sgL11Dzd5q
— Andy Phillips (@AndyDPhillips) October 20, 2015
What a joke. Completely ridiculous https://t.co/2ZhXtOwGBm
— Jake murphy (@Jake_Murphy82) October 20, 2015
I'm a member, I don't go every week but it's nice to know it's an OPTION to attend! Smh that this is an issue! https://t.co/SRKK5X4DZ6
— Jason Fanaika (@jayFITA51) October 21, 2015
This is all voluntary. Same as mass and chapel that every team does. The fact that this is even an issue is lame! https://t.co/xzvSeDZZHM
— Tenny Palepoi (@Palepoi95) October 20, 2015
@BodyMARCedUp @JFurKSL this is so dumb just some haters prob
— Hiva Lutui (@HivaG_) October 21, 2015
The classes had been featured in a May article in the Deseret News written by Amy Donaldson.
